stem: A 32-year-old trauma client has received 12 liters of IV crystalloids for hemorrhagic shock over the last 6 hours. Based on the documentation in the Intra-Abdominal Pressure (IAP) Log, which finding indicates the need for emergent surgical decompression?

tabs.title: Intra-Abdominal Pressure Log
tabs.content:
TimeIAP (mmHg) via FoleyPeak Airway Pressure
14008 mmHg (Normal)22 cm H2O
160018 mmHg (High)34 cm H2O
1800 (Now)28 mmHg (Critical)48 cm H2O

tabs.title: Clinical Findings
tabs.content: Current: Abdomen is tense and board-like (distended). Urine output has dropped from 30 mL/hr to 4 mL/hr. Client on ventilator: Tidal volume is decreasing; PCO2 is rising to 58.

tabs.title: Surgical Guidelines
tabs.content:
Medical Management: IAP 12â€“20 mmHg (Sedation, paralysis, NG decompression).
Surgical Decompression: IAP > 20 mmHg with new organ failre (e.g., Oliguria, High Airway Pressures).

options.text: The intra-abdominal pressure of 28 mmHg with acute oliguria
The massive fluid resuscitation of 12 liters
The rising PCO2 on the ventilator
The board-like rigidity of the abdomen

rationale.correct: This client has developed **Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS) (a1)**. High-volume fluid resuscitation causes bowel swelling and fluid shifts into the peritoneum. When the pressure (IAP) exceeds **20 mmHg** and causes new organ dysfunction (Oliguria: 4 mL/hr, High Airway Pressures: 48), the only definitive fix is an emergent surgical laparotomy to 'leave the belly open' and relieve the pressure. If not treated, the pressure will crush the IVC (stopping preload) and the kidneys (stopping urine).
clinicalPearls: IAP is measured via a transducer on a Foley catheter (Bladder pressure).
ACS is common in massive fluid resus, burns, or abdominal trauma.
High airway pressures on the vent occur because the swollen belly is pushing the diaphragm into the chest, leaving no room for the lungs to expand.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing 'Board-like rigidity' (a4) because it sounds like peritonitis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While the belly is hard, the *indicator for decompression* in ACS is a specific measurement (Pressure > 20) relative to organ status. Always choose the objective measurement when evaluating for surgical intervention.

mnemonic.title: Belly-Tight
mnemonic.expansion: Pressures high. Urine low. Lungs can't blow. Open the belly!
